definition:
Let $(X,d)$ be a metric space, $f\colon X\to X$ a function, and let
$\epsilon>0$. An $\epsilon$-pseudo-orbit for $f$ is a sequence
$\{x_n:n\in{\mathbb{Z}},\, a<n<b\}$, where
$-\infty\leq a<b \leq \infty$, such that $d(x_{n+1},f(x_n))<\epsilon$
for all $a<n<b$. A periodic pseudo-orbit is an infinite pseudo-orbit
$\{x_n\}$ such that there is some $p$ with $x_{n+p}=x_n$ for all n.

Given $\delta>0$, the pseudo-orbit $\{x_n: a<n<b\}$ is said to be
$\delta$-shadowed by the orbit of $x$, if $d(x_n,f^n(x))<\delta$ for all
$a<n<b$.
